reviewText: I'm about to re-review this collection.I'm too lazy to start a NEW post, but here it is.It's called "PROS and CONS"Now that I have had both the "The First Official Season One"and the "Alliance Entertainment" Version I am going to give you where I think both versions had pros and cons.Packaging: About the same quality actually.--> In some ways having the HARD BOX (Alliance) was actually nicer and in some ways looked better on a shelf. The Layout of the packaging inside, (Official) acutally did a better job allowing people to release the disc without having to remove other disc that were in the way.--> Nice addition of the booklet for the (Official) package. Might have been a plus there.DVD--> Label--> It's nice to have the episodes listed on the discs as well as the characters from the series (Official). However, I will not condemn the labeling of the (Alliance) discs as they were nicely uniform as well. (You needed to know which disc had what it was printed nicely on the package just as you opened it.)Opening Sequence:(Official)WarningTOEI LOGO ++Stationary screen with Episodes numbered +[Play All]CHARACTER and DIGIMON printed. Nothing fancy.[Opening Title Sequence on Every Episode]Plus or Minus depending on how you like to watch these things.[AUDIO] in Episodes--> The one thing I DID notice was there was a great deal of Audio Correction used. I put emphasis on Episode "Wizardmon's Gift" late in the series. There was a pretty noticeable Audio glitch in that episode after Wizardmon got attacked by Myotismon. That and many other spots were normalized very nicely.[Animation] in Episodes--> Either it's the frame Rate or Resolution or something, but the animationhas some blending issues making the picture pop a bit and not blend smoothlybetween frames. The LARGER the screen is that these discs play on (or the higher thedefinition) the more pronounced this problem will be. (Let's not get started on Retinascreen Macbook Pros)  Perhaps it's a frame-rate translation, but I feel that it becomes especially noticeable when characters are moving quickly across a scene.In a number of episodes the Color seems to take a loss especially the earlier episodes where there was a high dependence on Watercolor backgrounds. Everything seems a bit more washed out at times.(ALLIANCE)Opening Sequence:WARNINGAlliance Entertainment Logo + Japanese Digimon ThemeTitle Screen Composed of:>> Play Movie and Episode AccessStationary Character from episode + small window with animated opening[Opening title Sequence only at the beginning of first episode on disc with ending title at end of disc] very convenient if you don't like hitting "NEXT" button to advance unnecessarily long titles. If you're like me, I like to just watch the Episode.[Audio] Obviously the downside of this release for reason mentioned before. Audio isn't terrible, however, there are areas where the spikes scream, quick get the remote - turn the volume down... now turn it back up. (-)[Animation]It could be because they used the original Japanese Video, but the animation definitely benefits from this. Much smoother visuals. (Definately a plus here)The way I see this, it's a preference. Which do you like better?Audio or Visual?Granted, I'm not telling anyone to get the Bootleg, however, I WILL create contrast to point out that if you merged the TWO you'd probably have the perfect product.[Oh. And my final Star Count remains at ***]

reviewText: I honestly never thought this day would come.  A legit copy of Digimon season 1?  Never.  Until now, that is!  This has the entire first season of Digimon: Digital Monsters.  This set was made for the kids (now young adults and adults) who watched the English dub, as there is no Japanese language track included. The great thing about this set, however, is that it is a complete season set-- not a volume set!  All 50 some episodes in one box.  Exciting, right?  On top of that, the quality is very, very good.Digimon is a favorite of mine, if you couldn't tell, and is definitely a series that new viewers could enjoy!  Check this out!

reviewText: I remember the late 90's when the first wave of Pokémon knock-off animes were coming out. This one was the best of the lot.It starts off with 7 kids at a summer camp. A strange storm whisks them all to another world with strange creatures called Digimon and they all realize that now have a unique electronic device called a Digivice that had some connection between them and these Digimon. As the story progresses and the secrets of the Digital World become known, it turns out that all 7 do indeed have a lot more in common that they originally thought.Despite the seeming childishness of the show, it is quite well-written and has a complex and layered plot. There was a direct sequel in season 2 and three more seasons with various connections to the original.This is the first time the complete first season has ever been available in the US on DVD. This is an 8-disc boxed set with a custom outer sleeve. All 54 episodes are included. The discs are all dual-layer DVD9s, which allow for quite decent video and audio quality. This set only uses the US dubs, but they were fairly good.

reviewText: This release of the complete (and, YES, OFFICIAL!) first season of Digimon: Digital Monsters is as official as it gets! Finally!For one thing, for the first time ever, you will see the OFFICIAL Toei Animation (the animators of "Digimon") logo on the back of the box (aka rear cover art) -- that's something you will NOT see on a bootleg and was not on all those past bootlegs from Canadian company Alliance Entertainment. I wouldn't be surprised that the Toei Animation logo WILL appear on these official videos (on your TV screen) themselves (yet another indication that this OFFICIAL set is not a bootleg).In addition, the company that released this official first season (of all 54 episodes), NewVideo, is the same company that works with major studios such as A&E;, The History Channel, and official videos of Major League Baseball (MLB). NewVideo puts out on DVD some of your favorite complete seasons of TV shows from A&E; and The History Channel, as well as documentaries from these two major networks as well as from other major networks.I also love how they spread out all 54 episodes across 8 discs -- a true indication of top-notch quality and care that went into the mastering of these NewVideo episodes (the Alliance set had it's 54 eps spread across only six discs, resulting in a bit poorer quality and some more noticeable artifacting). Also, in the Alliance set, you don't get the opening titles/theme and closing credits/theme on every single episode -- you will on this NewVideo set (just like when we watched them on Fox Kids and ABC Family back in 1999-2002).I'm not going to complain about the packaging of the NewVideo set. Why? Because virtually every studio (Even Warner, CBS Video, and Disney) are using the exact same packaging and DVD storage units as this "Digimon" set -- it's the current trend for DVD and Blu-Ray "set" storage.If you are a DigiFan, get this set -- fast! But do please order it out of WalMart as it is the least expensive ($80 Amazon vs. $34 WalMart....it's a no-brainer!) You'll also see these NewVideo sets at DVD Planet and DVD Empire in the $40s and $50s.
summary: It's Official: Even has Toei Animation Logo

reviewText: A long time coming, this DVD of Digimon Season (Digimon Adventure) brings back the classic series from the late 90s. Having been only 4 when this Season made its first run I had only watched some episodes, a VHS or two, and The Movie. This being so I was really excited to watch the season in it entirety. So after 2-3 weeks, I got through the entire 54 episodes, and this is what I found.It was, okay. It started off kinda weak, but progressed as it went along. The Dark Masters Arc was the best of the four arcs, but the best episode, by far, was Home Away From Home directed by Mamoru Hosoda, who had already done the franchise's pilot short movie, also know as Digimon Adventure, and would go on to do Our War Game. The series itself, for me, was kinda mixed. It had a good epic journey feel to it, and I would say that, with the exception of the first arc, I certainly enjoyed myself. But then I also think that the series had far too many main characters and that the relationship between the Digi-Destined was a bit two dimensional. And I didn't really like the ending much, felt tacked on. Overall, though, I would give it a good B. I would recommend this to anyone who had grown up with the series or for anyone who has kids. Not really for anyone else.

reviewText: As someone who grew up watching the Digimon series as a young child this was one of favorites and will always have a special place in my heart for that reason. There may not be  a whole lot in the way of character development, but that isn't the point of this show. Digimon succeeded in its goal of entertaining us and giving us mostly memorable characters. Watching this again as an adult years later the show holds up pretty well. One huge advantage of the show is that it knows its limit and does not run for to long the episode count is just about perfect. We get several adventures and explore the world of Digimon and meet a ton of cool characters that are well designed. Another interesting/semi-frustrating aspect of the show was digiveloution (seriously I think we all remember waiting for Patamon to digivolve for pretty much the entire series, but seeing MagnaAngemon was worth it). All in all for anyone who was a fan of the show or is just interested in a well designed animated series with a ton of cool characters this set is definitely worth the price.

reviewText: "And so it begins..." as the very first episode was titled. Ever since my first experiences with Digimon's 1st season in Fall 1999, I knew it was, is, and always will be better than Pokemon in every imaginable way. To this day, most Pokemon say nothing more than their own names ALL THE TIME! (In human ears at least.) Now you own all 54 episodes of Digimon's 1st season in this incredible 8-disc DVD set, provided you don't pay arms-and-legs for it, like the whole SRP of 80 bucks. Since those early episodes, the show has slowly-but-surely changed my life for the better. I was suddenly able to speak in my own head, which I'd never done beforehand. All 54 original USA prints of the show are here, from the humble beginnings, to Devimon's reign & defeat, to Elvis-sque Etemon's reign & defeat, to the endless bad deeds of Myotismon & his goons, to Myotismon's first re-birth & defeat as the show's very first Mega-level Digimon, VenomMyotismon, to the Dark Masters' saga (which included the rebirth-and-final-demise of MetalEtemon), to the epic rise-and-fall of Apocalymon. You can also find this set, slipcover and all, in the Seasons 1 to 4 Deluxe set! Too bad Nicktoons ain't running the show very often, including Fusion, when I edited this review in January 2014. Lucky thing I own the season sets to make up for such bad business moves on Nick's part. I still wish that Cinedigm would release a Digimon Movie Collection, which should include the original theatrical movie from 2000 and its 4 TV movies from 2005. While we wait for such a collection to ever happen in the USA in real life, please enjoy this must-own trip down Digi-Memory Lane, especially if you're a veteran fan of the show, such as myself. You can also share it with new fans, both young and old, who wanna start the show from the very beginning. One of THE greatest Anime shows ever is finally on authorized whole season sets on DVD!
summary: Bootlegged sets out, Authorized sets in, especially for Digimon!

reviewText: It's a complete digi-DVD release with all 54 digi-episodes from 1999 to 2000. All on 8 digi-discs. One of my favorites I remembered watching as a kid back when it first came out. This was around the time when Fox Kids was now starting to mostly air both animes and their own shows (unlike back in the early to mid-90's when they were airing shows made by Warner Bros., Hanna-Barbera, Jim Henson and others besides airing their own shows they made). Here all 54 episodes:*1. "And so it begins..."*2. "The Birth of Greymon"*3. "Garurumon"*4. "Biyomon Gets Firepower"*5. "Kabuterimon's Electro Shocker"*6. "Togemon in Toy Town"*7. "Ikkakumon's Harpoon Torpedo"*8. "Evil Shows His Face"*9. "Subzero Ice Punch!"*10. "A Clue from the Digi-Past"*11. "The Dancing Digimon"*12. "DigiBaby Boom"*13. "The Legend of the DigiDestined"*14. "Departure for a New Continent"*15. "The Dark Network of Etemon"*16. "The Arrival of Skullgreymon"*17. "The Crest of Sincerity"*18. "The Piximon Cometh"*19. "The Prisoner of the Pyramid"*20. "The Earthquake of Metalgreymon"*21. "Home Away from Home"*22. "Forget About It!"*23. "WereGarurumon's Diner"*24. "No Questions, Please"*25. "Princess Karaoke"*26. "Sora's Crest of Love"*27. "The Gateway to Home"*28. "It's All in the Cards"*29. "Return to Highton View Terrace"*30. "Almost Home Free"*31. "The Eighth Digivice"*32. "Gatomon Comes Calling"*33. "Out on the Town"*34. "The Eighth Child Revealed"*35. "Flower Power"*36. "City Under Siege"*37. "Wizardmon's Gift"*38. "Prophecy"*39. "The Battle for Earth"*40. "Enter the Dark Masters"*41. "Sea-Sick and Tired"*42. "Under Pressure"*43. "Playing Games"*44. "Trash Day"*45. "The Ultimate Clash"*46. "Etemon's Comeback Tour"*47. "Ogremon's Honor"*48. "My Sister's Keeper"*49. "The Crest of Light"*50. "Joe's Battle"*51. "The Crest of Friendship"*52. "Piedmon's Last Jest"*53. "Now Apocalymon"*54. "The Fate of Two Worlds"Highly recommend this for the Fox Kids and Digimon fans who grew up with this show. And this year (2013), there will be a few separate volumes containing only a few discs from the complete set. But they will only be for collectors who don't want to waist too much money for this complete set.
summary: A Digi-Favorite to Fox Kids and Digimon Fans
